title: ISic003290. Epitaph for Priska(?)

Facsimile Images

Apparatus criticus

  • Text based on photograph;
  • line.1: Ferrua, Noy: [---]Î¹Ï‚ ÎºÎ±[---]; Korhonen: [Î Ï]á¿–ÏƒÎºÎ±
  • line.2: Libertini, Korhonen: [á¼”Î¶]Î·ÏƒÎµÎ½; Ferrua, Noy: [---]Î·Ï‚ ÎµÎ½[---]
  • line.3: Liberini, Noy: Î´Î­Îº[Î±]; Ferrua [---]Î·Î´Îµ Îº[---]; Korhonen: [á¼”Ï„]Î· Î´Î­Îº[Î±]
  • line.4: Ferrua: á¼Ï„Ï‰(Î½); Korhonen: [á¼Î½ Î§ÏÎ¹Ïƒ]Ï„á¿· (the space between Ï„Ï‰ and the previous letter could be justified if we suppose an abbreviation: á¼Î½ Î§Ï(Î¹Ïƒ)Ï„á¿·); Chaniotis: [Î¼Î®Î½Î±Ï‚ á½€Îº]Ï„Ï;
  • Ferrua, Noy and Korhonen 2001 interpreted the symbol as a menorah, but later Korhonen as a palm

English translation

Marta Fogagnolo

Prisca lived for 18 (?) years.

Italian translation

Marta Fogagnolo

Prisca visse per 18 (?) anni.

commentary

The epitaph is Jewish, as revealed by the symbol of a menorah. Korhonen rejects the Judaic provenance of the inscription believing the symbol to be a palm, but the feet of the menorah seems to be present even if not rubricated. Korhonenâ€™s supplement to l. 4 á¼Î½ Î§Ï(Î¹Ïƒ)Ï„á¿· (the same abbreviation as in RQUA 10 (1896) 38 nr. 67), for this reason, cannot be supported: moreover, the space does not seem sufficient. If one assumes that a few characters are missing on the right, the integration of Chaniotis (ap. SEG) [Î¼Î®Î½Î±Ï‚ á½€Îº]Ï„Ï is also not possible. One possibility would be to integrate the numeral Î´ÎµÎºÎ±Î¿ÎºÏ„Ï. For the name Prisca in another Latin inscription from Catania from the imperial period, see CIL 10.1088*199 = ISic003241.
